G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which guarantees that tenants shall not be subjected to significant interference with the use and enjoyment of their rental premises by the landlord or landlord’s agents.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 283-84 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that a landlord’s activities causing substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment give rise to liability, even where the landlord may not have acted maliciously.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court expressly explains that breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment turns on the landlord’s conduct and not on intent, and that liability can arise where serious interference with the tenancy is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted. This recognizes landlord liability for substantial interference with quiet enjoyment without requiring malicious action. The opinion then applies that standard to possible omissions in addressing criminal activity on the premises.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action… then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies… and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that a landlord’s activities causing substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment give rise to liability, even where the landlord may not have acted maliciously.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a tenant need not prove malicious or intentional conduct; instead, negligent conduct, i.e., “some degree of fault,” is sufficient for liability where the landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with quiet enjoyment. While the case focuses on whether a strict liability statutory violation alone suffices (it does not), it affirms that non‑malicious negligent interference by a landlord can give rise to quiet enjoyment liability, which matches the proposition.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: In Simon v. Solomon, supra at 101, we interpreted the new statute and concluded with respect to civil liability it was not necessary for a tenant to show malicious intent to recover against a landlord; we said that the statute covered “at the least” the reckless conduct that had been shown in that case. Id. Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving “some degree of fault,” by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: Defendant’s actions also fall within the scope of the protections articulated in *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982), which held that landlords may be liable where their actions cause significant disruption to tenants’ enjoyment of their residences.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord can be liable when its conduct—here, allowing repeated sewage flooding—interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment and caused significant emotional injury. The court explains that “quiet enjoyment” covers serious interferences with the character and value of the leased premises and that § 14 liability extends at least to reckless interference with quiet enjoyment, including foreseeable emotional harm. That aligns with the proposition that landlords may be liable where their actions cause significant disruption to tenants’ enjoyment of their residences.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”
